description: Perhaps related to clump. Compare hump, hunch; lump, lunch, etc.

entries.meaning: (UK) A traditional building material mostly made of chalk or clay.
examples: The manor-house stands near the church, and is a large convenient old house built of clunch, stone, &c. with good gardens and walks adjoining to the river side.

verbs.description: clunch (third-person singular simple present clunches, present participle clunching, simple past and past participle clunched)

examples: As William Wallace felt the bank giving away under his feet, he clunched the other boy firmly by the arm.
